title: Jeff Novitzky opens up on Barry Bonds, BALCO investigation
text:
Barry Bonds was found guilty of obstruction and served a one-month house arrest before the conviction was overturned in April. (Photo: Ben Margot, AP)
3 CONNECT 19 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE LAS VEGAS — Jeff Novitzky wants to set the record straight.
During a recent interview with USA TODAY Sports, the former federal agent said he and the government did not set out to entrap Barry Bonds, the retired home run king who was indicted on perjury and obstruction charges and accused of lying to a grand jury after his name surfaced in connection with the 2003 raid of the Bay-Area Laboratory Co-Operative.
Bonds was found guilty of obstruction based on the testimony he gave to a BALCO grand jury and served a one-month house arrest before the conviction was overturned in April.
USA TODAY
Jeff Novitzky, responsible for BALCO bust, aims to clean up UFC
“We did everything that we could to try to prevent him from not telling the truth,’’ said Novitzky, who spearheaded the investigation into performance-enhancing drugs that led to the prosecution of Bonds. “Up front, he was obviously given immunity, so there should have been no worries about being prosecuted for anything he said. We told him and his attorney time after time after time, ‘Just tell the truth. We’re not looking to set you up here. Just come in and tell the truth.’ And he didn’t do it.’’
Novitzky said he was “a little disappointed’’ that the Bonds’ conviction was overturned.
“But ultimately, I’m asked, ‘Hey, was it all a waste of time?’ I don’t think it was,’’ Novitzky said, adding that federal agents use it as an example to keep other witnesses from lying. “It transcends any steroids thing. …That helps the entire system. Because if it witnesses don’t tell the truth, the whole system breaks down.’’
He also dismissed speculation that the case cost millions of dollars.
“It wasn’t extensive,’’ he said. “It wasn’t like I spent six or seven years traveling the world talking about Barry Bonds.
“When I was with the FDA, I carried a dozen to 15 cases at a time, equally dedicating time and investigative work to it. It wasn’t as if the Barry Bonds investigation was all we did. It was actually a very small portion and percentage of what I did over the years.’’
